block.p: Stones' Mild Horses Plan Troubles Animal Lovers

A plan to sedate more than 300 horses at a Belgrade race track where a Rolling Stones concert on July 14 is expected to draw more than 100,000 people has ignited rage among Serbian animal lovers, Reuters reported yesterday. O.R.C.A., the country's largest animal protection society, said that the noise and vibrations of the concert would be extremely harmful to the animals and added that sedating them is not the answer. The society said that if it failed to persuade the organizers to move the concert from the Hippodrome, Belgrade's largest fenced space, it would appeal directly to the Stones -- including Mick Jagger, above -- who have never performed in Serbia. ''I believe we'll succeed, since such a reputable band will not allow such a stain on its record,'' said Elvir Burazerovic, the president of O.R.C.A.
A Book Club of One

The Canadian author Yann Martel, below, who wrote the best-selling novel ''Life of Pi,'' wants the country's prime minister, Stephen Harper, to pay more attention to the arts. So Mr. Martel is sending him some reading. Mr. Martel said he was upset that Mr. Harper had appeared to pay no attention during a recent ceremony honoring Canadian artists, Reuters reported. ''But he must have moments of stillness,'' Mr. Martel said. ''For as long as Stephen Harper is prime minister of Canada, I vow to send him every two weeks, mailed on a Monday, a book that has been known to expand stillness.'' First up: ''The Death of Ivan Ilyich'' by Leo Tolstoy. There was no immediate comment from Mr. Harper's office. Mr. Martel said he would post all selections and other developments on the Internet at whatisstephenharperreading.ca.
'Survivor' Heads for China

China will be the location of the 14th edition of the CBS reality show ''Survivor,'' Variety.com reported. American productions on the mainland have been rare, but China has become more open. The CBS series will be the first American network show to be filmed there, Variety said.
Kirov Ballet Plans A City Center Visit

The Kirov Ballet and Orchestra will perform at New York City Center for the first time when it appears there next year, from April 1 to 20. Under the artistic direction of Valery Gergiev and the director of the ballet Makhar Vaziev, the company from St. Petersburg, Russia, will dance repertory classics including Petipa's ''Kingdom of Shadows'' from ''La Bayad√®re''; Fokine's ''Scheherazade'' and ''Chopiniana''; Gorsky's ''Grand Pas de Deux'' from ''Don Quixote''; Balanchine's ''Jewels'' and ''Ballet Imperial'' and Forsythe's ''Septet.'' Tickets go on sale on Friday. Tickets for the 75th Radio City Christmas Spectacular go on sale at 9 a.m. Sunday. The show, featuring new scenes and Rockette performance numbers and new Rockette costumes, will run from Nov. 9 through Dec. 30 at Radio City Music Hall.
Gere's Kisses Reach Court

India's overburdened judicial system has two new cases after three lawyers filed complaints against Richard Gere, 57, for kissing the actress Shilpa Shetty, below, 31, at an AIDS awareness rally in New Delhi, The Associated Press reported. Public displays of affection are largely taboo in India. In one complaint a lawyer accused the actors of committing ''an obscene act,'' the Press Trust of India reported. Two other lawyers filed another complaint in Ghaziabad, a town on the outskirts of New Delhi, naming Ms. Shetty and private television channels for showing videos of the incident. Ms. Shetty said the hug and kisses were not obscene and that the public was overreacting. Yesterday, her representative, Dale Bhagwagar, declined comment on the court complaints but said, ''The media should concentrate on the cause of AIDS awareness rather than making an issue out of kisses.''
